did.abstract: The Soviet Union Mormon Subject Files contain materials on the Church of Latter-day Saints within Russia in the post-Soviet period.

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: Keston College, originally founded in 1969 as the Center for the Study of Religion and Communism with the named changed to Keston College in 1974, collected and publicized details about religious persecution behind the Iron Curtain, becoming “the voice of the voiceless.” After the collapse of communism in the 1990s, Keston College moved to Oxford and downsized due to decreased funding. The name eventually changed to Keston Institute. In 2007, the Institute transferred the Keston Archive and Library to the newly created Keston Center for Religion, Politics, and Society at Baylor University.

Keston collected, verified, translated, and disseminated information received from believers in the Soviet Union, Poland, Romania, Czechoslovakia, Hungary, Yugoslavia, Bulgaria and other communist countries. The Keston Archive and Library housed numerous letters, petitions, reports and underground publications (Samizdat) from believers of various denominations along with officially published books and periodicals.
The Keston Center collected documents on Mormons in the Soviet Union from 1990-1999 with the bulk of the content focused on 1996-1999.

Joseph Smith, the founder of Mormonism, was the first to suggest Russian missionary work. He commissioned two men to go to Russia, but circumstances ultimately prevented the trip. The first baptism on Russian soil occurred in 1895. However, none involved were ethnically Russian. While there was occasional Mormon activity within Russia throughout the 1900s, organized missionary work appears to have begun in 1990. Within the following year, Mormonism “received national recognition” (Miller). As of 2021, there was no temple in Russia, although one was announced in 2018.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The Soviet Union Mormons Subject Files contain clippings, newspapers, email correspondence, abstracts, a fax, a report, a magazine, and a press survey. The majority of the content focuses on the attempts to register the religion as a whole as well as individual groups, the impact of the 1997 Law on Religion, and the abduction and release of two Mormon missionaries. Some key terms and concepts in the documents include missionaries, history of the Mormon Church, Joseph Smith, 1997 Law on Religion, cults, and registration.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The Keston Center received the Soviet Union Mormon Subject Files in two folders. The content has been divided by specific thematic subjects and organized chronologically.
The Soviet Union Mormon Subject Files are arranged in one series: I. General.
